A variant (STC 21460.3) lacks "And are to be sold by Philip Scarlet" in imprint.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT NOBLE, TRUELY VALOUROUS, AND HEROICK GENTLEman, WILLIAM Lord CRAVEN, BARON of HampÅ¿teed, MARSHALL, &c.
div.p:
THe ardent affection wherewith the beÅ¿t & Å¿ublimeÅ¿t Spirits have ever embraced the Sonnes of the MuÅ¿es, is not in any example Å¿o apparent, as in that matchleÅ¿Å¿e pattern of true Valour and Magnificence, ALEXANDER the Great; who having finiÅ¿ht the ConqueÅ¿t of PerÅ¿ia, and hearing every day of more Victories, did thus expreÅ¿Å¿e his Å¿orrow and diÅ¿contented affection; Think you to pleaÅ¿e me with any news, unleÅ¿Å¿e ye can tell me that HOMER is alive again? Such was his ambitious love to Poetrie. Under protection of this invincible example, I boldly make my Approaches. My Lines are alreadie drawn and perfected, whereby I am reÅ¿olved to attempt your LordÅ¿hips Favour; and I hope I Å¿hall winne the Å¿ame without any danger or repulÅ¿e. Yet do I not think to carrie it by any advantageous Å¿urpriÅ¿e, or forcible irruption; but onely by a free and voluntarie yeelding, which you may eaÅ¿ily perform, without any derogation to your Honour and Valour. And Å¿eeing now my Å¿peech is to a Souldier, give me leave in that little that I have to Å¿peak, to keep the Å¿ame dialect. ForaÅ¿much as I am now to expoÅ¿e my Å¿elf to a World
of Enemies, I thought it fit to marÅ¿hall theÅ¿e my lines after a warlike order. I have prefixed the approbations of my judicious in the front of this Book, to be as it were a Vantguard. Then followes in the middle my own Poem, which I account as the Main; and upon this I do moÅ¿t of all relie. Then I have reÅ¿erved in the laÅ¿t place Å¿ome few Elegiack VerÅ¿es; which becauÅ¿e they have alreadie paÅ¿t the Pikes of Å¿harpeÅ¿t cenÅ¿ures, and come off cleare in the judgement of the world, I make them my laÅ¿t refuge, and have placed them (as you may Å¿ee) in the Rear. In this order I Å¿tand readie to receive the aÅ¿Å¿aults of envious Carpers, and curious Criticks. I do not Å¿tand in any fear of your Honourable acceptation, and gracious interpretation of theÅ¿e my labours. The name and Å¿ubject of my Book, which is GÆ²STAVÆ²S Battels, is enough to aÅ¿Å¿ure me from all doubts & Å¿uÅ¿picions. Seeing you have not thought much to Å¿pend your beÅ¿t bloud in defence of his cauÅ¿e, I cannot think you will be backward to patronize the memorie of his Name.

closer.signed: The unfeigned Admirer of your Heroick Vertues, JOHN RUSSELL.

div.head: To the Candid Reader.
div.p: LEÅ¿t any Cynicall Critick Å¿hould compare my book to the Town of Mindas, which being but a Å¿mall Citie, was notwithÅ¿tanding beautified with Å¿tately gates; I am in this reÅ¿pect forced to Apologize for my Å¿elf, and my learned Friends, who have adorned this Å¿mall volume of mine with their ample Approbations. Know then, Courteous Reader, that I could not Å¿ubtract theÅ¿e EncomiaÅ¿ticks, without apparent wrong to the Å¿ubject of my Book: for you Å¿hall finde that they have imitated that cunning Engraver, who had with Å¿uch art inwrought his own Image with the Image of Minerva, that they could not be Å¿eparated without defacing of both: Å¿o have my Friends here interwoven my moÅ¿t undeÅ¿erving Name with the Å¿ublime praiÅ¿es of GUSTAVUS, that the one cannot be Å¿eparated from the other, without manifeÅ¿t disfiguring of the Poem. BeÅ¿ides, there are Å¿ome that are more delighted with brief & conciÅ¿e Epitomes, then with larger TreatiÅ¿es: theÅ¿e VerÅ¿es which I have premiÅ¿ed, Å¿eem to have contracted that which I have more amply handled, the Honour and PraiÅ¿e of GUSTAVUS the Great. And to conclude, that which theÅ¿e Criticks would fain make an argument of arrogance and oÅ¿tentation, Å¿eems to me a perÅ¿picuous teÅ¿timonie of my timorouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and modeÅ¿tie, in that I dare not enter into the world, without Å¿o many to guard me and uÅ¿her me the way. Farewell.

div.head: TO HIS FRIEND THE AVTHOVR, IN DEFENCE OF HIS Heroick Poem.
div.l: WHat wilt thou anÅ¿wer, Poet, for this wrong,
To make a King thy Subject and thy Song;
A King, whoÅ¿e Fame and long-liv'd actions Å¿carce
Can be contain'd in meaÅ¿ure of a verÅ¿e?
O inconÅ¿iderate MuÅ¿e! Of him is't fit
That every budget brain and common wit
Should write a farthing Pamphlet? Every one
At's death can have a verÅ¿e in braÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿tone.
Thus will cenÅ¿orious Criticks talk, and thoÅ¿e
That th' Empire claim of Poetrie and ProÅ¿e.
Yet care not. Once GÆ²STAVÆ²S was a Å¿coffe,
And Tinker call'd; at laÅ¿t came bravely off:
He clipt the Eagles wings, and took from thence
A quill for thee, Fabritius: art thou Å¿ince
Silent? Go, take thy pen, grave Doctour, write:
Thy MuÅ¿e methinks this Poem might excite.

closer.signed: J. PULLEN, Fellow of Magd. Coll.

div.head: TO HIS FRIEND THE AÆ²THOÆ²R of this Heroick Poem.
div.l: I Nothing finde unhappie in thy Book,
But (what's not thine) the Å¿ubject. When I look
Upon thy MuÅ¿e, and finde it full of bloud,
Yet I conclude thy Vein is Å¿ound and good,
And Å¿hall live long by that which is not thine,
But lively repreÅ¿ented in thy line.
That Hero's death thou doÅ¿t with life declare,
And in that which thou giv'Å¿t thou'lt Å¿urely Å¿hare.

closer.signed: R. BULKLEY, Fellow of S. Johns Coll.

div.head: To my Friend MaÅ¿ter RUSSELL, upon this enÅ¿uing Poem of the King of Swedens Battels.

lg.l: 'TWas a Proud Greek, whoÅ¿e vaÅ¿t Ambition
Pin'd for new Worlds, who vow'd his Counterfeit
Should be pourtraid on pain of death by none,
But beÅ¿t Apelles. Pride Å¿urnam'd him Great.
And 'twas a prouder TuÅ¿can, miÅ¿employd
His dying thoughts about his Elegie;
Charging his Marble might be rather void,
Then not adorn'd by Prince of Poetrie.
Thus did not Sweden taint his greatneÅ¿Å¿e: He
Suffers all ProÅ¿e, or VerÅ¿e. Nor doth his Shade
DiÅ¿turb, but help the ArtiÅ¿t. Deitie
Accepts an offring from the meaneÅ¿t trade.
Friend, thy firÅ¿t-fruits are Å¿acred. GÆ²STAVES Name
Is then (O MuÅ¿es) more authenticall.
Nor Å¿hall't be HereÅ¿ie in verÅ¿e to claim
Aid from live Names, and Å¿till Imperiall.
He Å¿hall preÅ¿erve thy Papers, and vent more
Then an enlarg'd Edition. His Name
Shall be thy Title too, and fill the doore
Of the rich Shop it lies in; like the Frame
Of Å¿ome rare FrontiÅ¿pice, with neat device
Tying unto it the Spectatours eyes.
So both in equall tye are excellent;
Thy Book's His Elegie, He its Monument.
WHat looÅ¿e ProÅ¿e could not pay to Swedens HerÅ¿e,
Thou haÅ¿t diÅ¿charg'd in thy Heroick VerÅ¿e,
Th' Intelligencers Feet, on which he'l runne
Now round the world, like a Å¿urveying Sunne.
'Twas greater art to chuÅ¿e thy Theme, then write
Some Poems. But to pen it in deÅ¿pite
Of others grief, or Å¿ilence, argues Love
Great as thy Art. And if the People prove
Thy hand hath rudely op't a publick wound
Newly clos'd up; the MagiÅ¿trate's not bound
(As Athens mulcted Phrenicus) to be
Their CenÅ¿or, and to fine thy HiÅ¿torie.
No: Let us know, our Guilt that MatchleÅ¿Å¿e Man,
WhoÅ¿e Dirge thou Å¿ing'Å¿t, hath murdred. Nay, I can,
And dare tell how too: 'Twas the fond exceÅ¿Å¿e
Of our big thoughts decreas'd his HappineÅ¿Å¿e;
WhoÅ¿e modeÅ¿t Soul we vext with reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e crie
Of love pretended, Proud Idolatrie.
His purer BreaÅ¿t divin'd aÅ¿much, while we
Mad men Å¿till tempted him with PropheÅ¿ie.
Oh! had this Frenzie reÅ¿ted in the heart
Onely of us the People, little Art
Might frame a Plea. But our great Rabbins too,
(Oh Learning, what huge miÅ¿chiefs mayÅ¿t thou do,
Seduc'd by Pride and Flatt'rie!) nay, thoÅ¿e Brains
That wear the Sacred Cappe, through all their veins
DeÅ¿cri'd infected bloud, whoÅ¿e tainted Å¿treams
Danger'd the Nations, whil'Å¿t noiÅ¿ome Å¿teams
Exhal'd as high as Heav'n. That Å¿tarrie Sphere,
Stranger to vapours, could not now be cleare.
Egypt examin'd Starres, and father'd lies
On their pure SubÅ¿tances: all MyÅ¿teries
Are pri'd into, and Å¿tretcht. The ChiliaÅ¿t
Takes Å¿ev'rall Å¿hapes; now poÅ¿es us in vaÅ¿t
Contemplative juÅ¿t nothings, and then Å¿lips
Into a CaÅ¿Å¿ock, picks th' Apocalyps,
And Å¿howes us Wonders, which poore I dare Å¿wear
His fleering heart well knew were never there.
The unclaÅ¿pt Book was read, the Signes unÅ¿eal'd,
The Trumpets, Phials, and the BeaÅ¿t reveal'd:
The Pope and CeÅ¿ar Å¿lain outright, and all
By GÆ²STAVE, and by Heav'n. This was his fall.
The Sinne was ours; the troubled Vertue his.
So Evil haÅ¿ted GoodneÅ¿Å¿e to her bliÅ¿Å¿e.
Now th' An'grams bluÅ¿h: and had not Pirrhus art
Excus'd the letter, when the Authours heart
Glow'd with a lie; by this time Levi had,
Like IÅ¿s'chars aÅ¿Å¿e, coucht under's burden, glad,
Though Å¿trong, to be releas'd. Let this Å¿uffice,
We all confeÅ¿Å¿e we Å¿lew him, and our eyes
Shall teÅ¿tifie our Å¿orrows. LYPSICH may,
And LUTZEN tell his Life Å¿ome half the way:
What we confeÅ¿Å¿e, tells all; perfects the Storie
More then the Annals of his living Glorie.
Oh! this ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion well-penn'd would be
His Chronicle, his Tombe, his Elegie.

closer.signed: T. RILEY, Fellow of Trin. Coll.

div.head: TO THE AÆ²THOÆ²R OF this enÅ¿uing Poem, MaÅ¿ter RUSSELL.
div.l: HOw dares thy mortall Fancie undertake
A Theme Divine, unleÅ¿Å¿e for Vertues Å¿ake?
The Germane Eagle, to advance thy skill
In praiÅ¿ing Swethland, lends a conqu'red quill.
Yet when thy Self and loftie Bird have done,
Neither are able to behold this Sunne.
Go Å¿trive to write, and caÅ¿t away thy pen:
Repent thy Å¿elf, and take it up agen.
Sometimes thy Å¿elf, and Å¿ometimes Swethland blame:
And midÅ¿t thy praiÅ¿es check his glorious Name.
Tell valiant Swethland, if thy Eagle brings
A flight too low, his GreatneÅ¿Å¿e clipt her wings.

closer.signed: CAESAR WILLIAMSON, Fellow of Trinit. Colledge.

div.head: To his ingenious Friend MaÅ¿ter RUSSELL, upon his Heroick Poem.
div.l: LEt thoÅ¿e Å¿oft Poets, who have dipt their brains
In am'rous humours, thaw to looÅ¿er Å¿trains.
Let Cupid be their theme, and let them pay
Service to Venus in a wanton lay:
And let theÅ¿e Rhymers of our Å¿ilken Age
Unlade their Fancies on an emptie page.
Mars is thy theme; thy MuÅ¿e hath learn'd to talk
The Cannon-language of the Warre, and walk
A loftie March; while thy faint readers dread
And tremble at each Å¿yllable they reade.
Leade on, Stout Poet, in thy Martiall Å¿tate;
And let theÅ¿e Pages on GÆ²STAVÆ²S wait,
Armed with verÅ¿e of proof: and thoÅ¿e that aim
To wound thy MuÅ¿e, or print upon thy Name
Their darts of malice, in their full purÅ¿uit,
Charm'd like thoÅ¿e Å¿tones thrown at the Thracian Lute,
May they forget their meÅ¿Å¿age, and in fierce
Career dance at the muÅ¿ick of thy verÅ¿e.
And if thoÅ¿e eyes, with pois'ned flame that Å¿hine
Like BaÅ¿ilisks, Å¿hed poiÅ¿on on a line,
To blot a Å¿yllable that Å¿ounds the leaÅ¿t
GÆ²STAVÆ²S Warre, Jove turn them to that BeaÅ¿t.
Then reÅ¿t GÆ²STAVÆ²S: do not change thy room
Within this Book, for any marble tombe.
Each line's a golden chain to hoiÅ¿e thee farre
'Bove Fate: then blaze as faÅ¿tned to a Å¿tarre:
And for theÅ¿e Leaves preÅ¿ented thee, a bough
Of Laurell Å¿hall adorn the Poets brow.

div.head: To his friend the AUTHOUR.
div.l: INgenious friend, that doÅ¿t Å¿o bravely Å¿ing
The conqueÅ¿ts of the Swethes Victorious King;
Who by thy thundring lines doÅ¿t Å¿eem to follow
AÅ¿well the tents of Mars, as of Apollo;
And in depainting of a bloudie fight
DoÅ¿t intermingle Terrour with Delight:
Though I could tell thee that thy verÅ¿es worth
Abundantly will gild and Å¿et them forth;
Although I might (without baÅ¿e flatterie) Å¿ay
Thy forehead doth deÅ¿erve a wreathe or Bay;
Yet I forbear: thy modeÅ¿tie is Å¿uch,
I dare not praiÅ¿e, at leaÅ¿t, not praiÅ¿e thee much.
Indeed what need'Å¿t thou my too Å¿lender praiÅ¿e,
To uÅ¿her thy Å¿o Å¿weetly-Å¿oaring layes
Into the world; Å¿ince that the very name
GUSTAVUS will more highly grace the Å¿ame,
Then if the rareÅ¿t Laureats choiÅ¿eÅ¿t quill
To pen thy praiÅ¿e Å¿hould Å¿hew its utmoÅ¿t skill?
How richly is thy work rewarded! See!
Thou mak'Å¿t GUSTAVUS live, GUSTAVUS thee:
And by thy loftie MuÅ¿e I know not now
Whether Å¿hall more be honour'd, he or thou.

Sweds GreatAnagram of GUSTAVUS
AÆ²GÆ²STÆ²S! Oh how could I dwell
Upon that Name! How often could I Å¿pell
Its every Å¿acred Å¿yllable; and when
I've done't a thouÅ¿and times, begin agen!
That Name who honours not, Oh may he be
O'rewhelm'd with never-dying infamie!
His bleÅ¿Å¿ed Memorie who adoreth not,
Oh may he be eternally forgot!
Thy book, my friend (if I do not miÅ¿take)
Will pleaÅ¿e and Å¿ell for Great GUSTAVUS Å¿ake.

closer.signed: STEPHEN JONES, of S. Johns Coll.

lg.l: HAve you not heard the ever-reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e Ocean
Beat on the Å¿hore with waves continuall motion,
Which fill our eares with Å¿ad and murm'ring tones;
JuÅ¿t like the dolefull Å¿ighs and hollow grones
Of thouÅ¿ands, that together have conjoyn'd
T' expreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿orrows of a wounded minde,
For Å¿ome diÅ¿aÅ¿trous Fate; perhaps the death
Of Å¿ome deare Prince, untimely reav'd of breath?
They fill the troubled aire with confuÅ¿e cries,
Which are reÅ¿ounded by the trembling skies;
Which theÅ¿e Å¿ad tunes Å¿o often do repeat,
That now the woodie ChoriÅ¿ters forget
Their wonted Å¿trains, and either Å¿tand as mute,
Or to theÅ¿e notes their warbling voices Å¿uit,
The willing aire inÅ¿tructing to expreÅ¿Å¿e
To humane eares Å¿oul-moving heavineÅ¿Å¿e.
Sweet Philomel now thinks upon her rape
And former wrongs; that Å¿he may fitly Å¿hape
A tune of lively Å¿orrow, and make known
The grief of others, fully, as her own.
Like this was that amazed time, when firÅ¿t
Our eares thoÅ¿e more then frightfull rumours pierc't,
Of great GuÅ¿tavus diÅ¿mall Fate; with whom
All then did Å¿eem their hopes and hearts t'intombe;
And did expreÅ¿Å¿e in Å¿ighs and drouping looks,
Sorrow enough t'have fill'd moÅ¿t Å¿patious Books:
You might have read, in thought-diÅ¿cov'ring eyes,
Volumes of Å¿ad and mournfull Elegies:
While Fame doth with a thouÅ¿and tongues reÅ¿ound
Such trembling murmures, as our hearts do wound.
My fainting Soul, not able to Å¿uÅ¿tain
So oft redoubled blowes, nor Å¿uch dire pain,
Sunk to the ground: then over all my limbes
A frigid Å¿weat and dewie vapour Å¿wimmes:
A Death-like Å¿leep clos'd up my eyes; and I,
As one eternally entranc'd, did lie.
But then methoughts my Genius did appeare,
And words of comfort whiÅ¿pred in mine eare:
Then led my airie Spirit by the hand,
Through darkÅ¿ome Å¿hades, to that Inferior Land
And Region, where Æ²nbodied Souls reÅ¿ide.
There what my fancied thoughts to me deÅ¿cri'd,
I now prepare unto the World in verÅ¿e,
By favour of the MuÅ¿es, to rehearÅ¿e.
ThoÅ¿e two Å¿o bloudie Battels there I view'd,
LypÅ¿ich and Lutzen, dreadfully renew'd:
But now more furious and a greater ire
Their bloud-enraged Å¿pirits did enfire.
Oh that thoÅ¿e raptures, which then fill'd my brain,
Would burn in my impris'ned Soul again;
That I might Å¿o in vivid colours paint
ThoÅ¿e dreadfull fights, as Å¿hould make Mortals faint
With horrour and amaze, and when they reade
My Bloud-beÅ¿prinkled verÅ¿e, their hearts Å¿hould bleed!
Divine Melpomene, whoÅ¿e chiefeÅ¿t glorie
ConÅ¿iÅ¿ts in Å¿ounding of a Tragick Å¿torie;
Fill me with vig'rous heat, and for a while
Let thy rapt Furie guide my iron Å¿tyle:
Send Virgils Genius to direct my quill,
His grave MajeÅ¿tick vein do thou inÅ¿till;
Or rather Lucans, whoÅ¿e Å¿o loftie rhymes
Do beÅ¿t befit the Genius of theÅ¿e times.
But oh! what Å¿udden numneÅ¿Å¿e do I feel
To damp my boiling bloud! and now I reel,
As when an EpilepÅ¿ie doth Å¿urpriÅ¿e
Some feeble mortall, and his Å¿enÅ¿es ties:
Or, when as the Cumean Sibyls breaÅ¿t
Some dire Prophetick Spirit hath poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿t;
She madly rages, Å¿truggles all in vain
To Å¿hake away her Furie-cauÅ¿ed pain:
She raves, Å¿he frets, Å¿he Å¿torms, and tears her hair,
Stamps with her feet, and like a GhoÅ¿t doth Å¿tare:
Mean while, within her rage-diÅ¿tracted Å¿oul,
And troubled thoughts, diÅ¿cording PaÅ¿sions roll.
Thus am I rackt, while to my working heart
My PhanÅ¿ie doth Å¿uch jarring thoughts impart.
For this to ev'ry Poet is enjoyn'd,
That he Å¿hall feel in his impreÅ¿Å¿ive minde
The reall Thoughts and PaÅ¿sions of all thoÅ¿e,
Whom he in verÅ¿e preÅ¿umeth to diÅ¿cloÅ¿e.
Judge what a world of diÅ¿cords circling runne
Within my breaÅ¿t, like Atomes in the Sunne,
That croÅ¿Å¿e, and meet, and meet, and croÅ¿Å¿e agen.
So many PaÅ¿Å¿ions of Å¿o many men,
And Å¿uch repugning thoughts torment my minde,
As when two Armies have with furie joyn'd:
Rage and Revenge march firÅ¿t, with burning Ire:
Dread, Fears, and Terrours make them to retire:
Then Shame, and Valour, with malicious Hate,
Their reinforced Troups precipitate:
They charge them home: theÅ¿e break, and Å¿catt'red flie

JuÅ¿t at this time a duskie MiÅ¿t did fall:
The Heav'ns lamented his Å¿ad Funerall,
And Å¿o amaz'd his Foes, that they forget
To bear away his Bodie: For as yet
Among a heap of Å¿laughtred Corps it lies;
A ruefull Spectacle to mortall eyes,
To Å¿ee him laid Å¿o low, that was of Late
The glorious Head of Å¿uch a mightie State.
But by this time the Swethes had recollected
Their Sp'rits, and now again their hearts erected.
StollhanÅ¿he, enraged with a furious courÅ¿e,
Leads on a Regiment of nimble HorÅ¿e,
Who gave th' ImperialiÅ¿t a charge Å¿o hot,
And with Å¿uch frequent volleys of their Å¿hot,
As they not able to endure, begun
To yeeld their ground, Å¿uch furious blowes to Å¿hunne.
Then the Å¿ad Swethes did raiÅ¿e a mournfull crie,
When on the ground their murdred King they eye;
WhoÅ¿e bloud-diÅ¿tained Corps in heavie Å¿ort
From furie of the Battell they tranÅ¿port.
Meanwhile the SwediÅ¿h Foot did backward beat
Th' ImperialiÅ¿t, and made them to retreat.
Grave Neels, a valiant and couragious Swethe,
That never car'd for wounds, nor fear'd for death,
His Yellow Regiment Å¿o bravely led,
That now they might have di'd their Name quite red.
And Winckle too with his Blew Regiment
At that Å¿ame time Å¿o Å¿toutly forward bent,
That now the Wall'nÅ¿teiners did gladly chooÅ¿e
Their ground and Cannon both at once to loÅ¿e.
But then the MiÅ¿t to Å¿uch a thickneÅ¿Å¿e grew,
That the enraged Swethes could not purÅ¿ue
This their advantage; but were then compell'd
To Å¿tand and pauÅ¿e untill the miÅ¿t diÅ¿pell'd.
At that Å¿ame time a Å¿udden Å¿trange affright
On part of the Imperiall Troups did light,
That with Å¿uch terrour Å¿truck their courage dead,
That Å¿traight they turn'd their bridles, and then fled;
Not once their eyes reflecting back, to view
If any foes behinde them did purÅ¿ue.
Some mutt'ring tongues a fearfull rumour Å¿pread,
That all their Troups were fully vanquiÅ¿hed.
Some fifteen hundred HorÅ¿e were then beheld
With Å¿wift Career to gallop out of field.
Fear taught them haÅ¿te, and made them cruell too;
For in their headlong Å¿peed their friends they Å¿lew:
Their Bedets and their Women in the Rear
They trampled down, and Å¿ome they kill'd with fear.
There many Ladies, who that day did wait
With trembling hearts upon their Husbands Fate,
Fling from their Coaches, then their HarneÅ¿Å¿e part;
(What will not fear enforce a tender heart?)
In Manly poÅ¿ture did theÅ¿e Females Å¿tride
Their Å¿turdie BeaÅ¿ts, and Å¿o away they ride.
TheÅ¿e fear-tormented Wights my Warlike MuÅ¿e
Doth Å¿corn to follow, when none elÅ¿e purÅ¿ues.
Return we to thoÅ¿e Noble Hearts, who ne're
Would Å¿hrink a jot, though all the world Å¿hould fear;
That now in midÅ¿t of fire and Å¿moke did Å¿trive
Their Enemies before them for to drive.
Now Pappenheim being come, did reinforce
Th' Imperiall troups with new Å¿upplies of HorÅ¿e:
He added Courage to their Å¿tagg'ring Bands,
And made them charge again with willing Hands.
He rang'd himÅ¿elf in the SiniÅ¿ter Wing,
Which (as he thought) oppoÅ¿ed Swethlands King.
But as his Cornets now Å¿tood ord'red fair,
And he himÅ¿elf did for the Charge prepare,
A Bullet from a Falconet is Å¿ent,
WhoÅ¿e deadly force his arm and Å¿houlder rent:
Soon it tranÅ¿coloured his Å¿hining Steel
With bloud, and made this haughtie Captain reel;
He that the town of Magdenburg did Å¿poil,
And levell'd all her buildings with the Å¿oil;
WhoÅ¿e Execrations, as we may preÅ¿ume,
Did haÅ¿ten on his unexpected Doom.
But when his Captains and Commanders Å¿aw
Their Generall his lateÅ¿t breath to draw,
He's Å¿lain, He's Å¿lain, aloud they all did crie;
Then facing it about, away they flie,
Ere they had fought one Å¿troke, or in the field
The faces of their Enemies beheld.
But thoÅ¿e Imperials, whom his preÅ¿ence Å¿et
On a freÅ¿h charge, Å¿tood to it Å¿tiffly yet,
And with Å¿uch maÅ¿Å¿ie Squadrons overlaid
The SwediÅ¿h Troups, that they were backward Å¿waid.
Here Coloredo, and TerÅ¿ica too,
With Picolomini, the fight renew
With no Å¿mall Furie, and with many hands
Which light upon Grave Neels and Winckles Bands.
The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e above the knee being hurt,
His Souldiers from the Battell did tranÅ¿port,
Though after this he did not long Å¿urvive.
And thou brave Winckle wert fetcht off alive
With double wounds. But thy Vice-Colonell
Was Å¿tricken down, and did not Å¿cape Å¿o well.
Though thus th' ImperialiÅ¿t victoriouÅ¿ly
Did for a while the SwediÅ¿h Squadrons plie,
And now his Cannon had reÅ¿um'd again,
Which erÅ¿t he loÅ¿t; yet for it was he fain
T' exchange Å¿o many of his braveÅ¿t men,
The flow'r of all his Infantrie, and then
So Å¿oon their deer-bought bargain to give over,
Which the bold Swethes quickly from them recover.
There did old Bruner on th' Imperiall part,
A skilfull Captain, loÅ¿e both life and heart.
The young Count Wall'nÅ¿tein by Å¿ome unknown hand
Was likewiÅ¿e there Å¿hot dead upon the Å¿and.
There Fulda's Abbot di'd, whoÅ¿e Å¿acred head
Was pierced by the rude and impious lead,
That never to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h yet would learn,
Nor be conjur'd a Mitre to diÅ¿cern
From a Å¿teel Helmet, but impartially
At all alike his unÅ¿taid force doth flie.
Here had the fierceÅ¿t of the Battell been,
Here likewiÅ¿e was the greateÅ¿t Å¿laughter Å¿een.
The Å¿turdie Swethes had learn'd to fight and die;
But never yet had learn'd to Å¿hrink or flie:
The ground, which erÅ¿t their warlike hands defended,
They cover with their Bodies now extended.
Death well might winne from them their lives; but loe,
Their ground he cannot force them to forgo.
But now KnipphauÅ¿en, who with watchfull eye
The Å¿laughter of his Vantguard did deÅ¿crie,
MoÅ¿t readie is to Å¿top encroaching fear:
He Å¿ends them up two Brigades from the Rear:
The one Count Thurn, the other Mitzlaffe led,
Who gladly did their waving Colours Å¿pread,
And marching forward with a Å¿peedie pace,
Their now triumphing Enemies do face.
Having within a reaching diÅ¿tance got,
They did Å¿alute them with their thundring Å¿hot,
Which without ceaÅ¿ing they Å¿o roundly pli'd,
That now th' Imperials hearts were terrifi'd:
Being Å¿o lately tired, they could not
For any Å¿pace endure a Charge Å¿o hot.
What could be done by Valour or by Skill,
Was there perform'd; they Å¿tand it out, untill
The eager Swethes by force and weightineÅ¿Å¿e
Expell'd them from the place they did poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e.
Once more th' Imperiall Cannon they had wonne;
And turning them, to thunder now begun
AgainÅ¿t the Wall'nÅ¿teiners. At that Å¿ame houre,
Bernard, that noble Duke, with all his Power
Of HorÅ¿e and Foot fiercely aÅ¿Å¿ails thoÅ¿e bands
And Regiments, where Coloredo Å¿tands;
Who did as then, like Å¿ome unmoved rock,
Receive th' impreÅ¿Å¿ion of his mightie Å¿hock:
At which the Duke did Å¿lacken his firÅ¿t heat,
And back again did orderly retreat.
But here once more the vap'rie miÅ¿t deÅ¿cended,
And for a while both Å¿ides from blowes defended.
But when this cloudie curtain drawn aÅ¿ide
Gave Å¿pace to both the Armies to be ey'd,
Wall'nÅ¿tein did two of his chief Captains Å¿end
To Å¿ee what now the Swethlanders intend.
At that time Bernard and KnipphauÅ¿en joyn'd,
And both together had their Troups combin'd:
Their Å¿hatt'red Regiments they did repair
With freÅ¿h Å¿upplies, and made them Å¿traight & Å¿quare.
TheÅ¿e Scouts return'd, and to their Duke relate
How that the SwediÅ¿h meant to iterate
The fight afreÅ¿h and did in Battell ray
Their bloudie EnÅ¿ignes once again diÅ¿play,
And orderly were marching on amain,
ReÅ¿olving for to conquer or be Å¿lain.
Duke Bernard doth eÅ¿pie th' Imperiall HorÅ¿e
Retreating from them in an even courÅ¿e;
Then twentie Cannons did he make to roar
With Å¿uch a vengefull furie, that they tore
Both HorÅ¿e and Man, defac'd both rank and file,
And their fair Martiall order quickly Å¿poil,
Making their troups confuÅ¿edly to Å¿how,
While on the graÅ¿Å¿e their mingled bloud doth flow;
And which before not any colour knew,
But the freÅ¿h green, is di'd with purple hue.
Here the proud Steed, who Å¿corn'd & Å¿purn'd the ground,
Stretcht dead upon the Å¿ame is quiet found:
And there another, who did fiercely neigh,
And bravely did his reared creÅ¿t diÅ¿play,
Is with a fire-wing'd bullet Å¿tricken dead,
And mangled lies without a creÅ¿t or head:
Here was a file of HorÅ¿emen cut in Å¿under
By direfull force of this reÅ¿iÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e thunder,
While th' untoucht HorÅ¿e do Å¿tart and fling about,
And Å¿o the next diÅ¿orderly do rout.
The SwediÅ¿h Cornets Å¿oon th' advantage Å¿pie,
And with a Å¿udden charge upon them flie.
Before it thundred; now a Å¿torm of hail
And Å¿maller Å¿hot their Å¿tagg'ring troups doth quail;
And then theÅ¿e haughtie Cavaliers begun
With Å¿wift and more diÅ¿ord'red pace to runne.
Their Infantrie no better then did fare;
TheÅ¿e alÅ¿o by the Swethes repulÅ¿ed are,
Who now preÅ¿t on, and pli'd their Volleys round,
And Å¿houldred out th' Imperials from their ground.
As when two Currents do adverÅ¿ely roll,
And Å¿eek each others motion to controll:
A while they Å¿eem pois'd with an equall force,
And both alike repell their Å¿patt'ring Å¿ourÅ¿e;
Till one of them aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted with a blaÅ¿t,
The others waves doth headlong backward caÅ¿t:
Thus did the Swethes by force and Martiall toil
Compell th' Imperials backward to recoil.
But thoÅ¿e that in the mud-wall'd Gardens lay,
Farre more Å¿ecurely for a while did play,
Under protection of thoÅ¿e earthen Banks,
Upon the Swethlanders encroaching ranks.
But they, enrag'd at this unequall fight,
Advanced tow'rds them with a vengefull Å¿pight;
And like a TempeÅ¿t Å¿torm'd upon their trenches,
Which Å¿oon with Å¿laught'red bloud their furie drenches.
And now the Sunne, wearied with this Å¿ad Å¿ight,
Began from them to hide his Å¿hining light:
He now did Å¿eem with his declining beams
To kiÅ¿Å¿e the Oceans azure-colour'd Å¿treams;
When lo a rumour was diÅ¿perÅ¿t by Å¿ome,
That Pappenheims Foot-Regiments were come:
Duke Bernard then rallies again his HorÅ¿e,
ReÅ¿olv'd t'aÅ¿Å¿ail them with his utmoÅ¿t force.
But when the Signall was again reÅ¿ounded,
The cheerfull Souldiers, as no whit aÅ¿tounded,
Strictly did each embrace his Camerade,
And, MuÅ¿t we charge them once again? they Å¿aid;

l.hi: Then let us bravely and with manly Hearts,

lg.l: And like true Souldiers, act our lateÅ¿t parts.
Then with Å¿uch rage and furie did they cloÅ¿e,
As if they had reÅ¿erved all their blowes
For this laÅ¿t onÅ¿et; and thoÅ¿e new-come Bands
Did quickly feel their over-weightie hands:
They found that though the light did Å¿till decreaÅ¿e,
Yet the Å¿tout Swethes would not their furie ceaÅ¿e.
After they had Å¿uÅ¿tained for a while
Their rough encounter, and no little Å¿poil,
They did betake them to a Å¿hamefull flight
Under protection of the wings of Night,
Leaving the field to their victorious foes,
Who on the Å¿ame their wearied limbes repoÅ¿e.
Among his wounded Friends and Enemies,
On the cold ground the conqu'ring Souldier lies;
And ne're complaineth of Å¿o hard a Bed,
Where VICTORIE her pleaÅ¿ing arms hath Å¿pread.

div.p: AN ELEGIE UPON THE IMMATURE AND MUCH LAMENTED DEATH OF that moÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian Souldier and Renowned Prince, GVSTAVVS THE GREAT, King of Swethes, Goths, and Vandals; &c.
CompoÅ¿ed immediately after the firÅ¿t rumour of his death, by JOHN RUSSELL.

div.head: An Elegie upon the death of the King of SWEDEN.

lg.l: WHat Å¿trange Å¿ad Å¿ilence doth the world aÅ¿tound?
Why doth not Fames Å¿till echoing trumpet Å¿ound?
She's grown forgetfull, or elÅ¿e hoarÅ¿e, I fear,
That we no more victorious Å¿ounds can heare.
'Twas but of late, when as the thundring noiÅ¿e
Of doubled triumphs, conqueÅ¿ts, and applauÅ¿e
Fill'd our Horizon, and the aire did ring
With Å¿houts of praiÅ¿se to Sweds victorious King.
Was this a dream and fanci'd apparition,
And now is vaniÅ¿ht like a fleeting viÅ¿ion?
Could all the world be thus deluded? No:
'Twas Å¿urely reall, and no feigned Å¿how.
ThoÅ¿e bloudie battels and thoÅ¿e diÅ¿mall fights
We lately heard, were not like vap'rie Å¿ights,
Compos'd of airie breath, which to the eye
Two dreadfull Armies grappling do deÅ¿crie.
TheÅ¿e, theÅ¿e were reall; and thy direfull Å¿teel
(Victorious Prince) Å¿hall after-ages feel:
And thoÅ¿e deep wounds, which in thy furious ire
Thou didÅ¿t inflict by force of thundring fire,
Shall leave wide Å¿carres upon the Germane land,
Which Å¿hall for ever to their terrour Å¿tand.
This thou haÅ¿t done alreadie, and amaz'd
RemoteÅ¿t kingdomes, where thy deeds are blaz'd.
But on a Å¿udden, loe! thou doÅ¿t appeare
To Å¿top in middle of thy full career:
All tongues are Å¿ilent, and our greedie eares
Heare nothing now but terrours, doubts, and fears.
Or Fame her Å¿elf is dead; or he that gave
Life unto Fame, is Å¿unk into his grave.
Fame cannot die. Oh! can he die, whoÅ¿e look
So many thouÅ¿ands dead at once hath Å¿trook?
What mortall durÅ¿t give him a wound, whoÅ¿e eye
Hath made grimme Death to Å¿tart and turn awrie?
Sure he's not dead: Swethland for grief would roar,
And make their grones heard to our EngliÅ¿h Å¿hore,
If he were dead, whom they have priz'd more deare
Then their own proper lives, and did not fear
To runne like Lions, at their Princes words,
Upon the mouthes of Cannons, points of Swords.
He's dead, I fear: For can he living be,
And we no Å¿poils nor further conqueÅ¿ts Å¿ee?
Can he be living, and not heard to thunder,
To batter cities, trample kingdomes under;
WhoÅ¿e very Å¿oul was fire Aethereall pure,
Such as no mortall bodies can endure?
His breath was direfull Å¿moke, and from his hands
Flew Å¿how'rs of iron balls, that quell'd whole lands.
Can that Sulphurious duÅ¿t, more quick then winde,
Once toucht with flame, in priÅ¿on be combin'd?
Not Å¿teel, nor iron, nor the hardeÅ¿t braÅ¿Å¿e
Can Å¿tay its furie for the Å¿horteÅ¿t Å¿pace.
Though mightie mountains preÅ¿t this living flame,
Yet would it tear them, and an entrance frame,
His HelliÅ¿h breath and diÅ¿mall noiÅ¿e to vent;
Nor would it ceaÅ¿e, till all its furie's Å¿pent.
Thus hath it been with Europes Northern Starre,
And Sweds Victorious Prince, made all for warre:
WhoÅ¿e Spirit, toucht with fire from heav'n, did blaze
Like to Å¿ome Comet, Å¿ent for to amaze
And Å¿courge us mortall wights; whoÅ¿e direfull breath
Doth Å¿hoot down vengeance, terrours, plagues, & death.
Had Turk, and Tartar, and the Triple Crown
That awes the ChriÅ¿tian world, and treadeth down
Monarchs as Å¿laves, themÅ¿elves in one combin'd;
This Heav'n-Å¿ent Furie had, like lightning winde,
Shot through them all; and, like to Å¿catt'red corn,
Their feeble Å¿quadrons had been rent and torn:
Till his CeleÅ¿tiall vigour were quite Å¿pent,
No Warres, no Ruines could his ire content.
But now his date is out, and his CommiÅ¿sion
Is Å¿topt from heav'n with a new Prohibition.
He's dead. Oh bitter word, enough to make
Stones for to weep, and iron hearts to ake!
So Å¿oon? alas! in Å¿o unwiÅ¿ht an houre
Is all our joy quell'd by Å¿ome Å¿ecret power?
Why do not we then breathe Å¿uch dolefull grones,
And poure Å¿uch melting tears, as Å¿hould hard Å¿tones
DiÅ¿Å¿olve into Å¿alt drops; that they and we
Might Å¿o expreÅ¿Å¿e one mournfull Elegie?
What! are we Å¿pent and drie? I Å¿ee no teares;
I heare no grones; no wailings pierce my eares.
Oh pardon me! I fear my faltring tongue,
DiÅ¿tract with troubled Å¿orrow, doth you wrong.
'Tis Å¿lender grief that doth by weeping vent;
And 'tis not much that can by tears be Å¿pent.
But this, this Å¿orrow, like a mortall wound,
Strikes deep, and doth our Å¿enÅ¿es quite aÅ¿tound;
Lies like a lump of lead or heavie weight
Upon our heart, and pincheth it Å¿o Å¿trait,
That neither Å¿igh nor grone can iÅ¿Å¿ue thence;
But lies as dead, and quite bereft of Å¿enÅ¿e.
Since then 'tis Å¿o we cannot weep; let's borrow
From others help, Å¿o to expreÅ¿Å¿e our Å¿orrow.
Ye gliÅ¿tring lamps above, ye Northern Å¿tarres,
That roll about the Pole your frozen Carres;
In Thetis waves plunge over head and eares,
That ye may have your fill of briniÅ¿h teares,
And by Å¿ad influence make the heav'ns to lowre,
And to the earth Å¿end down a weeping Å¿howre;
But chiefly on that place, that curÅ¿ed ground,
Where Adolph firÅ¿t receiv'd his mortall wound.
Let never graÅ¿Å¿e nor verdant herb grow there;
Nor any tree, nor ground it Å¿elf appeare.
Let it be all a lake, whoÅ¿e face may look
JuÅ¿t like the colour of th' Infernall brook;
Like pitchie Styx, or black-Å¿tream'd Acheron;
Or like Cocytus, or dark Phlegethon:
That it may Å¿eem to all a mourning vail,
That doth the Å¿urface of that ground empale.
And let its murm'ring waves make Å¿uch a noiÅ¿e,
As may expreÅ¿Å¿e to us the dolefull voice
Of Å¿ome that crie, that roar, that Å¿hriek, that grone;
Of Å¿ome that mourn, that weep, that wail, that mone:
That after-ages to their children may
Tell this Å¿ad Å¿torie, when they paÅ¿Å¿e that way;
TheÅ¿e Å¿ouls do mourn for Swethlands conqu'ring King:
But theÅ¿e, whoÅ¿e clamours fearfully do ring,
Are Å¿uch as in this place di'd by his power,
And thus expreÅ¿Å¿e their horrour to this houre.
Meanwhile, Renowned Prince, Å¿leep thou Å¿ecure,
No further pains nor travels to endure.
The dreadfull Cannons, which Å¿o oft did roar
And thunder in thy eares, Å¿hall now no more
DiÅ¿turb thy reÅ¿t, nor force thee to ariÅ¿e
In Å¿udden haÅ¿te: glut now with Å¿leep thine eyes,
While that a Quire of Angels in a ring
Shall round about thee bleÅ¿Å¿ed muÅ¿ick Å¿ing.
